title: Fortinet FortiCloud SSO Zero-Day: Cross-Account Device Hijacking Under Active Exploitation (CISA KEV)
affected_products: FortiOS (all versions with FortiCloud SSO enabled)

timeline.event: Multiple Fortinet clients report unauthorized access to FortiGate firewalls despite running latest patches
Fortinet locks out two malicious FortiCloud accounts used in attacks
Arctic Wolf confirms automated attack campaign with config exfiltration within seconds
Fortinet globally disables FortiCloud SSO to stop ongoing exploitation
FortiCloud SSO re-enabled with version enforcement; CISA adds to KEV catalog
CISA releases guidance; FortiOS 7.4.11 patch available

simple_summary.what_happened: A critical zero-day vulnerability (CVE-2026-24858) in Fortinet's FortiCloud Single Sign-On allows attackers with any FortiCloud account to access devices registered to OTHER organizations' FortiCloud accounts. This is a separate vulnerability from the previously patched CVE-2025-59718. Attackers exploited this flaw starting January 20, 2026, using two malicious FortiCloud accounts to compromise devices across multiple organizations. Fortinet was forced to globally disable FortiCloud SSO on January 26 to stop the bleeding.
simple_summary.who_is_affected: Organizations using FortiCloud SSO authentication on FortiOS, FortiManager, FortiAnalyzer, or FortiProxy devices. This affects enterprises worldwide that use Fortinet's cloud-managed authentication for their network security infrastructure. FortiManager Cloud, FortiAnalyzer Cloud, and FortiGate Cloud services are NOT affected. Organizations using custom IdP (including FortiAuthenticator) are also not impacted.
simple_summary.what_attackers_do: Step 1: Create or compromise a FortiCloud account with at least one registered device. Step 2: Exploit CVE-2026-24858 to authenticate to devices registered under OTHER FortiCloud accounts. Step 3: Download victim organization's firewall configuration files (contains sensitive network topology, rules, credentials). Step 4: Create new local administrator accounts on the compromised devices. Step 5: Create VPN-enabled user accounts for persistent remote access. Step 6: Arctic Wolf observed this entire attack chain completing within seconds, indicating fully automated exploitation.
what_you_should_do: Immediately disable FortiCloud SSO: System > Settings > Switch 'Allow administrative login using FortiCloud SSO' to Off
Upgrade to FortiOS 7.4.11 or wait for upcoming patches for other product versions
Audit all local administrator accounts - delete any unrecognized accounts
Review VPN user accounts for unauthorized additions
Check device configurations for unauthorized changes
Rotate all credentials that may have been in exported configurations
Enable multi-factor authentication for all administrative access
Monitor for connections from unknown IP addresses to management interfaces
simple_summary.why_this_is_serious: This vulnerability allows cross-tenant attacks through Fortinet's cloud authentication service. Any attacker with a FortiCloud account could potentially access any other organization's Fortinet devices that have FortiCloud SSO enabled. The attacks were automated and completed config exfiltration and admin account creation within seconds. Fortinet firewalls protect critical network perimeters - compromised configurations expose network topology, security rules, and potentially credentials. This is the SECOND critical Fortinet auth bypass in January 2026, raising serious questions about the security of cloud-managed network infrastructure.

tactics.description: Abusing FortiCloud SSO to gain unauthorized access to other tenants' devices
Creating rogue administrator accounts on compromised FortiGate devices
Exfiltrating firewall configurations containing sensitive credentials

tactics.technique_name: Impair Defenses: Disable or Modify Tools
tactics.description: Modifying firewall rules to allow attacker traffic
Creating VPN-enabled accounts for persistent remote access

detection_guidance.summary: Monitor for unauthorized administrator account creation, suspicious FortiCloud SSO logins, configuration exports, and VPN account additions. Review audit logs for access from unexpected FortiCloud accounts.

log_sources.description: Administrative login events, account creation, configuration changes
SSO authentication events and device access logs
Centralized logging of all FortiGate events
Correlated alerts for admin account creation and config changes

what_to_look_for.description: New local administrator accounts created without authorization
what_to_look_for.log_field: logid=0100032001 or action=user-add with admin privilege

what_to_look_for.description: Firewall configuration exported or backed up unexpectedly
New SSL-VPN or IPsec VPN users added without authorization
SSO logins from FortiCloud accounts not belonging to organization
Multiple admin actions (login, config export, account creation) within seconds
what_to_look_for.log_field: Time correlation of multiple admin events

immediate_actions.description: System > Settings > Switch 'Allow administrative login using FortiCloud SSO' to Off
Review all local admin accounts and delete any unrecognized entries
Review SSL-VPN and IPsec VPN users for unauthorized additions
Upgrade to patched version when maintenance window permits
Compare current config against known-good backup for unauthorized changes
Change all credentials that may have been exposed in exported configs
